facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 383 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 383 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated August 10, 1960 of Kerala High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 10, 1960 of the Kerala High Court in Appeals Suit Nos. 577 and 751 of 1958 and 40 of 1959.

facts.text: Kerala High Court appeals: Suit Nos. 577 and 751 of 1958 and 40 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: dated August 10, 1960 of the Kerala High Court in Appeals Suit Nos. 577 and 751 of 1958 and 40 of 1959.

facts.text: Kerala High Court dismissed appellant's suit for recovery of possession of certain property and mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from a judgment of a single Judge of the Kerala High Court dismissing the appellants suit for recovery of possession of certain property and for mesne profits.

facts.text: Only question of law is whether appeals could be heard by single Judge of High Court; other questions are purely facts.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the only question of law which arises in this appeal is whether the appeal companyld be heard and disposed of by a single Judge of the High Court. The other questions raised are purely questions of fact.

facts.text: Suit instituted on February 10, 1950 in district court of Kottayam.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was instituted on February 10, 1950 in the district companyrt of Kottayam which was later transferred by it to the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge, Meenachil sometime in the year 1956

facts.text: Suit transferred to court of Subordinate Judge, Meenachil sometime in 1956.

anchor.surface_text: which was later transferred by it to the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge, Meenachil sometime in the year 1956 and was substantially decreed in the appellants favour on July 30, 1958.

facts.text: Suit substantially decreed in appellant's favour on July 30, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Meenachil sometime in the year 1956 and was substantially decreed in the appellants favour on July 30, 1958.

facts.text: Appeal by first defendant Tirumalaya Gounder against decree.

anchor.surface_text: Three appeals were preferred against it. One was by Tirumalaya Gounder, the first defendant, and another in January, 1959 by H. B. Mohammad Rowther, 8th defendant.

facts.text: Appeal by 8th defendant H. B. Mohammad Rowther in January 1959.

anchor.surface_text: One was by Tirumalaya Gounder, the first defendant, and another in January, 1959 by H. B. Mohammad Rowther, 8th defendant.

facts.text: Appellant preferred appeal against adverse part of decree.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had also preferred an appeal against that part of the decree which was adverse to him.

facts.text: Three appeals heard together and disposed by common judgment on August 10, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: All these -appeals were heard together and disposed of by a ,common judgment on August 10, 1960

facts.text: High Court allowed appeals of defendants 1 and 8, dismissed appellant's appeal.

anchor.surface_text: and the appeals preferred. by defendants I and 8 were allowed by the High Court while the appeal preferred by the appellant was dismissed.

facts.text: Suit and appeals valued at Rs. 3,000.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants suit and the appeals taken by the respondents from the District Court and the Subordinate Judge were both valued at Rs. 3,000

facts.text: Travancore-Cochin High Court Act 5 of 1125 M.E. (1949 A.D.) in force at time suit instituted.

anchor.surface_text: At the time the suit was instituted the Travancore-Cochin High Court Act 5 of 1125 M.E.  Corresponding to 1949 A.D.  was in force.

facts.text: Under Travancore-Cochin High Court Act ss.20 and 21, appeals over Rs.1,000 heard by Division Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 20 of that Act read with S. 21 all appeals to the High Court valued at an amount in excess of Rs. 1,000 had to be heard by a Division Bench companysisting of two Judges of the High Court.

facts.text: Travancore-Cochin High Court Act repealed by Kerala High Court Act No.5 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid Act was, however, repealed by the Kerala High Court Act, 1958 being Act No. 5 of 1959

facts.text: Kerala High Court Act 5 of 1959 received President's assent on February 6, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: which received the assent of the President on February 6, 1959 and came into force on March 3, 1959.

facts.text: Kerala High Court Act 5 of 1959 came into force on March 3, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: assent of the President on February 6, 1959 and came into force on March 3, 1959.

facts.text: Under s.5 of Kerala High Court Act 1959, single Judge jurisdiction extended to appeals not exceeding Rs.10,000.

anchor.surface_text: The reason why the appeals were heard by a single Judge and number Placed before a Division Bench was that under s. 5 of the Kerala High Court Act 5 of 1959 the jurisdiction of a single Judge of the High Court to hear and dispose of appeals from an original- decree was extended to appeals in which the value of the subject matter did number exceed Rs. 10,000.

facts.text: Appeals placed for hearing before single Judge, overruling appellant's plea for Division Bench.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals were placed for hearing before a single Judge overruling, we are informed by learned companynsel, the appellants plea that they should be only heard by a Division Bench.

facts.text: Supreme Court declined to interfere with High Court findings of fact due to no grave errors.

anchor.surface_text: it is the settled practice of this Court number to interfere with a finding of fact arrived at by the High Court unless it is satisfied that in arriving at the finding of fact the High Court had been guilty of -rave errors.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant unable to point out grave errors in single Judge's findings.

anchor.surface_text: We gave opportunity to learned companynsel to point out to us if the findings arrived at by the learned single Judge of the High Court are vitiated by any grave errors. But he was unable to point out any.

facts.text: Supreme Court declined to permit arguments on findings of fact.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, declined to permit him to address us on the findings of fact.
Though this provision does not detract from the power of this Court under Art. 136 to entertain an appeal from a decision of a single Judge,

Article 133, cl. 3 of the Constitution clearly provides that notwithstanding anything in the article no appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from a judgment, decree or final order of one Judge of a High Court unless Parliament by law otherwise provides.

concepts.interpretation: No appeal to Supreme Court from single Judge of High Court unless Parliament provides otherwise; does not detract from Art. 136 but influences practice.

anchor.surface_text: Garikapati Veerara v. N. Subbaiah Choudhury in which the following propositions were laid down That the legal pursuit of a remedy, suit, appeal and second appeal are really but steps in a series of proceedings all connected by an intrinsic unity and are to be regarded as one legal proceeding. The right of appeal is not a mere matter of procedure but is a substantive right.

concepts.interpretation: Right of appeal is substantive vested right governed by law at institution of suit; can only be taken away expressly or by necessary intendment. But applies to right to appeal, not to mode of hearing (bench composition).

anchor.surface_text: Radhakrishan v. Shridhar 1 .
